title: Frogs and Toads
description: Leap into the world of these amazing amphibians: the frogs and toads.
author: OneZoom

template_data.title: Amazing Amphibians
template_data.window_text: More than three quarters of amphibian species are frogs and toads, the rest are caecilians, salamanders and newts. The scientific name for frogs and toads is Anura which means 'without tail'.
template_data.comment: This is a public domain image

template_data.title: A Tale of tails
template_data.window_text: No fully grown adult frogs or toads have a tail. Even the so called 'tailed frogs' don't really have a tail. Male tailed frogs have something which looks like a tail, but actually it is used for reproduction, not for swimming!

template_data.title: Bright colours
template_data.window_text: Many frogs and toads are poisonous and have bright colours to warn anyone that to try and eat them would be a bad idea.

template_data.title: Pumpkin toadlet
template_data.window_text: The pumpkin toadlet is an example of a poisonous anuran with brightly coloured skin. They also have a flourescent skeleton which can be seen under UV light, take a look at the video below. It's not clear whether their UV reflectivity is used to attract a mate or used like their bright skin to deter predators.

template_data.title: Frog or Toad?
template_data.window_text: We typically call anurans 'toads' if they have a warty apparance but frogs and toads are not clearly separated into two different branches of the tree of life. So, the pumpkin toadlet isn't really a toad any more than it's a frog.

template_data.title: True toads
template_data.window_text: If any branch of the tree of life could represent toads it would be this the 'true toads' scientifically known as Bufonidae. Most of the species in this branch are referred to as toads, but not all...

template_data.title: Harlequin frogs
template_data.window_text: For example the harlequin frogs are within the true toads, so it's probably best not to think too much about wether something is a frog or a toad!

template_data.title: Chytrid fungi
template_data.window_text: Sadly, most of these beautiful harlequin frogs are threatened with extinction because of an infectious disease caused by chytrid fungi. Pictured here is the skin of an infected harlequin frog, the arrows point to the 'zoospores' through which in chytrid fungi is spread. Scientists have brought many wild populations of harlequin frogs into captivity to protect them from the chytrid disease and prevent total extinction of the species.

template_data.title: Find your frog
template_data.window_text: With over 7000 species of frogs and toads, there's a lot more to see. Try exploring the tree of life for yourself to find out more.
